Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study of the 'shape' of STEM educational assessment data will exploit recent advances in computational topology, machine learning and cognitive science. Applications of computational topology to learning theory are both new and innovative. It is anticipated that these new tools will provide critical insights into student learning of Calculus.

Funded by NSF's Research on Education and Learning (REAL) program, this early concept grant for exploratory research will apply advanced topological, geometric, and Bayesian methods to analyze the shape of data generated by students taking Calculus via a massive open online course (MOOC) system (and other data sources). This project will link data analyses from three leading learning platforms in the service of better understanding student learning of Calculus. One potential high payoff is the deployment of richer analyses of test and performance data to support a recommendation system to support to students reaching their learning goals. Further, the project will seed a new community of researchers across disciplines that typically do not interact. The proposed line of work has the potential to fundamentally change the way we think about assessment data in support of mathematics learning and perhaps other STEM content.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the Shape of Educational Data project, we were interested in better understanding student learning that occurs during online math-related courses. We approached this research topic from a number of different academic areas including topology, geometry, machine learning, educational psychology, learning analytics, educational measurement, and computer science. 

To increase the capacity of researchers to study questions about student learning, we hosted a meeting that brought leaders in the mathematical community, who are experts in topology and geometry, to work with researchers who run learning platforms that collect a lot of data on how students learn, and those with related expertise (e.g., educational psychologists).

After this meeting, the presenters wrote journal articles summarizing their presentations and these were published in the Journal of Learning Analytics and can be accessed here: http://learning-analytics.info/journals/index.php/JLA/issue/view/405/showToc. Because this is an open access journal, these articles are available online for researchers and the general public to access. The articles discuss a number of important methods and findings related to student learning in math-related courses. Some articles describe important online resources for instructors, including WEPS, WeBWork, inVideo, and ASSISTments. Other articles discuss how topology and geometry can be used to examine patterns of students’ flow through online courses or clusters of students in these courses. Other studies identify critical variables that help to understand student learning including students’ tendencies to learn content conceptually versus memorizing facts, their perceptions of the importance of math, their basic number sense skills, as well as some variables that are unique to online courses, including participation in online discussion boards, and the amount of time taken to grade the work of peers. These results highlight that the inclusion of attitudes, basic math skills, and approaches to learning, all based on educational theory, in addition to the online data, is important in understanding student learning within online courses. In addition, after more research is conducted on student learning in online systems, this information could be used to build a recommender system within online platforms to help improve student learning.

This line of work has the potential to fundamentally change the way we think about assessment data in support of mathematics learning and other STEM content. We believe that increasing the communication between researchers who study student learning in math from multiple angles was a critical contribution of this work, which will increase the amount of high quality future research in this area.
